ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Sheffield - Page
ai_page.body:
If your property needs repair or alteration

  • Your housing options in Sheffield
  • Are you eligible to join the housing register
  • If your property needs repair or alteration
  • If your current housing is not adequate
  • Alternative housing options
  • Becoming a Sheffield City Council tenant

If your property needs repair or alteration

If you are considering moving from your current property, we may be able to help you remain where you are.
If you are a current council tenant, your neighbourhood officer will assess your situation. Visit Neighbourhood offices for their contact information. However, your reasons for wanting to move may not result in a priority award.

Council properties needing repairs

If you want to move because you need repairs to your Council home, we may be able to resolve them.
Go to Request a repair to your property to see if your issue(s) can be resolved.

Decoration grants for your home

If you sign up for a council property, you will be responsible for decorating it. However, depending on the decorative state of the property, it may be assessed for a decoration grant.
A grant be in the form a B&Q electronic voucher that can only be used for items classed as decorating and cleaning supplies. You can get confirmation of this at the viewing and collect at when signing up for one.
Check if you can get a grant at Decoration grants for your home.

Alter your property

If you are thinking about altering your council home, you must ask for permission from us in writing before you start the work. 
Please look at Altering my property to see what you need to check with us first before making the alteration.

Housing improvement projects

We have agreed a £300m, 5-year investment plan for council housing in the city. To find out if your home is on the programme for improvements, visit Housing improvements and get in touch with us. The priorities for the programme are:

  • protecting the building fabric
  • reducing the cost and number of responsive repairs required
  • improving the energy efficiency of homes

Repairs for a housing association property

You don’t need to start a housing application if your housing association property needs repairs.
Report this to your association, and they will be able to help you resolve your issue.

Repairs for privately rented property

With private rented accommodation, the repairs could be your landlord’s responsibility, and you may not need to start a housing application.
If you are having difficulties contacting your landlord, our Private Rented Housing Team may be able to help. Go to Report disrepair in private rented properties.

Contact Council Housing Service

  • Ask us a question
  • 0114 293 0000 (Monday to Friday, 8am to 5:30pm)
  • Housing and Neighbourhood Service
    PO Box 5967
    Sheffield S2 9GH

Want to talk to someone right now?

ai_business_case.letter:
To the CEO,

Subject: Recommendations for Improving Customer Experience and Service Efficiency Based on Customer Feedback

Based on recent user feedback and usability analysis, I present key insights and suggested enhancements to our online housing service pages. These initiatives aim to improve customer satisfaction, streamline processes, and reduce administrative overhead, ultimately saving the council money.

1. Positive Feedback Recognition:
   - The feedback indicates that users appreciate clear information but desire more straightforward access to forms and process timelines. If our current content successfully addresses other queries, I commend the web team for maintaining clarity on general housing services. Keep up the good work in providing comprehensive and accessible information.

2. Specific Improvement Areas and Impact:
   - **Implementation of Direct Access to Online Forms:**
     Currently, the information about requesting permission for property alterations is somewhat indirect, prompting users to "look at" specific pages. By embedding prominent, direct links to the online permission request form within the relevant guidance sections, we can significantly reduce user effort and confusion.
     - *Impact:* Simplifies the process for customers like David, encouraging more online submissions and reducing phone inquiries, thereby lowering call centre costs and processing times.

   - **Clear Definition of Process Timelines:**
     The existing content lacks explicit timelines, which causes uncertainty and frustration.
     - *Recommendation:* Include specific estimates (e.g., "most decisions are made within 4-6 weeks") alongside the link.
     - *Impact:* Setting clear expectations improves customer trust, decreases follow-up inquiries, and speeds up decision cycles. It also minimizes the need for manual follow-ups, saving staff time.

3. Technical and Content Enhancements:
   - Incorporate FAQ-style sections within the relevant pages addressing common questions such as "How long will my permission request take?" and "What documents do I need to upload?".
   - Use headings and bullet points for faster scanning.
   - Ensure mobile-friendly design for smartphone users like David, providing seamless experience that encourages online interaction rather than phone or letter communication.

4. Broader Service Efficiency:
   - Automated notifications (e.g., email or SMS updates) for each stage of the permission process could further mitigate concerns about delays and improve transparency.
   - Live chat or quick messaging features could supplement written updates, especially when web chat is unavailable.

**Summary of Recommendations:**
- Add prominent, clickable links directly to online permission forms within relevant guidance texts.
- Provide estimated processing times for approval processes clearly on each relevant page.
- Enhance page layout with concise FAQs to cover common customer concerns.
- Implement automated updates to keep tenants informed at each stage.
  
By applying these improvements, we can create a more intuitive, transparent, and efficient service platform. This will increase customer satisfaction, reduce reliance on manual staff intervention, and ultimately lead to cost savings for the council.

I recommend prioritizing these modifications in our upcoming website update cycles.

Respectfully,

[Web Manager Name]
Usability and Service Efficiency Lead
